text.text: While at GE: Digital, my primary project has been building px-vis, a charting library and set of charts for the Predix design system (PDS).

Px-vis itself is a set of semi-standalone web components with which, one can build charts. From these building blocks, my collegue and I have built a number of reusable, customizable chart components, including the following types of charts:

Before I joined GE, the Predix Design System was using Highcharts as a base for PDS charts. Besides licensing issues, customization of both visual and interaction design, the ability to support custom features, and chart performance were starting to be concerns. When I joined and was given ownership over the PDS visualization effort, I decided to move us over to pure d3.js in order to alleviate these issues. While it was more work to get started with than a prebuilt charting library, it gave us full control to create the visualizations and features we needed to drive the Industrial Internet of Things.

Px-vis includes a series of novel features, such as hybrid svg-canvas charts, using web workers for data processing, a specialized canvas renderer to maintain 60fps frame rate, and a customizable toolbar allowing end developer hooks to create custom interactions on the chart.
One of the greatest challenges in creating this charting library is creating an open system which allows the end developers who consume our web components a high degree of customization.
